#Text= Whether other companies would have complied with such requests : this is very hard to tell . I believe however that it is very plausible that companies such as Google , Skype or Facebook would comply with such requests if they came from a government . "

column1: #Text=" In summary : unless you go through great lengths to log through to several computers in multiple countries , you work in a clean virtual machine , you use private browser settings ( do n't accept cookies , no plugins for Firefox , etc. ) and use tools such as Tor , it is rather easy for any service provider to identify you . "
#Text=" Finally : I prefer not to be quoted on any sentences in which I make statements on the capabilities or actions of any particular government . "

column1: #Text=Views of a security expert
#Text=Wikinews also consulted French IT security researcher Stevens Le Blond on the issues surrounding the case , and the state-of-the-art in monitoring , and analysing , communications online .
#Text=Le Blond , currently presenting a research paper on attacks on Tor to USENIX audiences in North America , responded via email :
#Text=Were the US Government to obtain the sought data , it would seem reasonable the NSA would handle further investigation .
#Text=How would you expect them to exploit the data and expand on what they receive from Twitter ?
#Text=My understanding is that the DOJ is requesting the following information :
#Text=1 ) Connection records and session times
#Text=2 ) IP addresses
#Text=3 ) e-mail addresses
#Text=4 ) banking info
#Text=By requesting 1 ) and 2 ) for Birgitta and other people involved with WikiLeaks ( WL ) since 2009 , one could derive 2 main [ pieces of ] information .
#Text=Logo of the Tor project .
#Text=First , he could tell the mobility of these people .
#Text=Recent research in networking shows that you can map an IP address into a geographic location with a median error of 600 meters .
#Text=So by looking at changes of IP addresses in time for a Twitter user , one could tell ( or at least speculate about ) where that person has been .
#Text=Second , by correlating locations of different people involved with WL in time , one could possibly derive their interactions and maybe even their level of involvement with WL .
#Text=Whether it is possible to derive this information from 1 ) and 2 ) depends on how this people use Twitter .
#Text=For example , do they log on Twitter often enough , long enough , and from enough places ?
